citation.article-title: A new obligately chemolithoautotrophic, nitrite-oxidizing bacterium, Nitrospira moscoviensis sp. nov. and its phylogenetic relationship

p.s: Description of Nitrospira moscoviensis sp. nov.
Nitrospira moscoviensis (Mos.co.vi.en'sis (L. adj. of Moscow, named after the place where this organism was first isolated)
Curved rods with 1–3 turns of 0.8–1.0 μm in width; 0.9–2.2 μm long, 0.2–0.4 μm wide, non-motile, gram-negative; multiplication by binary fission.

Obligate chemolithotrophs that oxidize nitrite to nitrate and use carbon dioxide as sole carbon source, no organotrophic growth, optimum growth at 39°C with a range between 33–40°C, pH optimum 7.6–8.0.
After consumption of nitrite, flocs of 1–2 mm in diameter appear due to the production of extracellular polymeric substances.
The DNA base composition is 56.9 ± 0.4 mol% G+C.

Accumulation of cells in pellets appear brownish; cytochrome difference spectra of cell-free extracts exhibit absorption spectra characteristics for b- and c-type cytochromes (maxima at 418, 524, 559 nm, shoulders at 531, 550 nm), cytochromes of the a-type were not detectable.
Habitat: iron pipes of municipal heating systems.
Type strain Nitrospira moscoviensis NSP M-1 isolated from an iron pipe of a heating system in Moscow is deposited in the culture collection of the DSM (Braunschweig, Germany) accession no. 10035.
